quoteFirst: These are the kind of men Leader Knox of the Sacramento Branch of the American Railway Union turned to when it became known that the National Guard had been ordered to Sacramento. In response to his call for assistance a train bearing 125 strikers fully armed, left Dunsmuir at
quoteLast: on July 4th, while another train with 100 strikers equally well armed, left Truckee at 4:20 P. M. on the same day. The destination of these trains was Sacramento.
title:
The "City Guard": A History of Company "B" First Regiment Infantry, N. G. C. During the Sacremento Campaign, July 3 to 26, 1894
Including a Brief History of the Company Since Its Organization March 31, 1854, to July 3, 1894
author: California. Infantry. First Regiment. Company B; Cook, Irving B.; Filmer, George; Hayes, W. J.; McCulloch, A.; O'Brien, William D.

quoteFirst: Humphrey Jardine disappeared from his home and his usual places of resort; the above reward will be paid to any person who shall give information as to his whereabouts, if alive, or the whereabouts of his body if he is dead. He was last seen at
quoteLast: on the above date in the Hampstead Road, and was then walking towards Euston Road. The missing man is about twenty-six years of age; is somewhat over six feet in height; of medium complexion; has brown hair, grey eyes, straight nose and a rather thin face, which is clean-shaved. He was wearing a dark tweed suit, and soft felt hat.
title: A silent witness
author: Freeman, R. Austin (Richard Austin), 1862-1943

quoteLast: to attack, with the two battle cruisers and the Glasgow. At 12.47 P. M. the signal to ‘Open fire and engage the enemy’ was made. The Inflexible opened fire at 12.55 P. M.

quoteFirst: “M E M.  That on Tuesday 8. Sept. 1741, about
quoteLast: at noon, was a most violent storm of wind and rain, which blew down St. Margarett’s Church Steeple and St. Nicholas at Lynn Regis, with the Weather-cock, &c. of All-Hallows Church in South Lynn, {920} Norfolk. Also the great West gabble-end, with a very large stack of chimneys, and the Weather-Hand of Middleton-Hall—And a great barn belonging to Henry Whiteman’s Farm at Tilney, with a small barn belonging to Thos.
title: The History of Lynn, Vol. 2 [of 2]
author: Richards, William, 1749-1818

quoteFirst: At 6.25 a.m. resumed our journey down the creek, which turned first west and then south-west, and at
quoteLast: encamped at a small pool; on the right bank of the creek wide grassy plains extended from three to five miles back towards a low-wooded ridge, but on the left bank the scrubby country came close to the creek.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations

quoteLast: . But how did he know it? He had been lying before me with his eyes closed and his ears apparently impervious to sound for about two hours. Twenty-five minutes later he remarked, "It is a quarter to one.

quoteFirst: On November 9 I saw Venus every half hour during the day up to one o'clock. I made a sketch at
quoteLast: I could now distinctly see the jagged terminator; the nature of which was so much like that of the moon as it was possible to conceive; except that if we compare the moon's terminator to a piece of network, that of Venus would be represented by a piece of fine lace.
title: The Life of Roger Langdon, Told by himself. With additions by his daughter Ellen.
author: Langdon, Roger, 1825-1894; Langdon, Ellen; Lambert, Henry Clifton [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Richardson died on Saturday night at
quoteLast: ?  She ate a little sago, with a tablespoonful of port wine in it, only half an hour before; and she said the whole of "Gentle Jesus, meek and mild," a little afterwards.  Her poor dear mother——’ and Mrs. Morton wiped her eyes.
title: An Australian Girl

quoteFirst: He was probably going to her house to ask her to lunch out with him. She looked at the pretty little gold watch that hung from her bracelet and saw that it was only
quoteLast: . She would be home in good time, and, thoroughly pleased with her morning's outing, she took a keen delight in pulling down the little window-curtain as she passed quite close to the Baron without being seen.
title: A Living Lie
author: Bourget, Paul, 1852-1935; De Villiers, J. A. J. (John Abraham Jacob), 1863-1931 [Translator]
